Iceland is known to the rest of the world as the land of Vikings and volcanos, an island caught between continents at the extremities of the map. Remote and comparatively inhospitable, it was settled only as long ago as the 9th century, and has seen little additional in-migration since. Even today, more than 90 percent of Iceland‚Äôs 390,000 residents can trace their ancestry back to the earliest permanent inhabitants, a Nordic-Celtic mix. The tradition of the Norse sagas lives on in the form of careful record-keeping about ancestry‚Äîand a national passion for genealogy. In other words, it is not the place to stumble upon old family mysteries.
But growing up in the capital city of Reykjav√≠k in the 1950s, neurologist Dr. K√°ri Stef√°nsson heard stories that left him curious. Stef√°nsson‚Äôs father had come from Dj√∫pivogur, an eastern coastal town where everyone still spoke of a Black man who had moved there early in the 19th century. ‚ÄúHans J√≥natan‚Äù, they called him‚Äîa well-liked shopkeeper who had arrived on a ship, married a spirited woman from a local farm, and became a revered member of the community.
The local census did record a man by the name of Hans J√≥natan, born in the Caribbean, who was working at the general store in Dj√∫pivogur in the 19th century‚Äîbut that was all. No images of the man had survived, and his time in Iceland was well before any other humans with African ancestry are known to have visited the island. If tiny, remote Dj√∫pivogur did have a Black man arrive in the 19th century, the circumstances must have been unusual indeed.
It was an intriguing puzzle‚Äîand solid grounds for a scientific investigation. Given the amount of homogeneity in the baseline Icelandic population, the genetic signature of one relative newcomer with distinct ancestry might still stand out across a large sample of his descendants. Geneticists thus joined locals and history scholars, and they pieced together a story that bridged three continents.
In 1964, University of Copenhagen law professor Knud Waaben wrote an extensive review of two men born into slavery in the 18th century who ended up fighting for their rights in Danish court. History had lost track of both men, according to Waaben, and only speculation was possible as to any later stages in the life of either.
One of the two men had been born on 12 April 1784 in the town of Christiansted on the Caribbean island of St. Croix. This small piece of land‚Äînamed by the French, intermittently occupied by the British, and technically owned by the Danish‚Äîexemplified the European-colonial squabbling that was playing out all over the Caribbean, not to mention the Americas and also the world in general.
The economies of St. Croix and the other Danish West Indies were driven almost exclusively by the Europeans‚Äô relatively new but insatiable need for sugar. Production of the stuff was based on an incomprehensible amount of slave labour. Generations of field-slaves and house-slaves endured brutal conditions across hundreds of sugarcane plantations as European sugar magnates became enormously wealthy. By the late 18th century, St. Croix held around 3,000 white people‚Äîalmost all men‚Äîplus about ten times as many Black slaves. Escape attempts were easily thwarted, since St. Croix afforded very few places to hide. Captured runaways were subjected to vicious beatings, public shaming, or both, even if they were children.
In Danish, he was called Hans Jonathan, as he was born into slavery and thus not entitled to a surname. His mother was a house slave named Regina, who at the time was in her mid-20s; her pregnancy was likely involuntary. Regina‚Äôs owner was a wealthy young widow named Henrietta Cathrina Sch√§ffer, who brought with her Regina and several other slaves when she married Ludvig Heinrich Ernst von Schimmelmann, a local judge from a prominent German-Danish family who was rapidly climbing through the political ranks of the Danish West Indies. In 1784, the same year Hans Jonathan was born, Schimmelmann was appointed Governor-General of the territory.
Hans was noticeably lighter-skinned than his mother, which suggested he was the offspring of Regina and a free white man. Exactly which free white man is unknown; historical records are vague, indicating only that the father in question was ‚Äúsaid to be the secretary‚Äù. In his extensive 2014 biography of Hans Jonathan, Icelandic anthropologist G√≠sli P√°lsson weighs the evidence and considers several possibilities. He points out that if ‚Äúthe secretary‚Äù is taken literally, the most logical match is a man named Hans Gram, who was the Schimmelmanns‚Äô scribe at the time (though Gram would later find minor fame in the United States as a composer). That said, ‚Äúthe secretary‚Äù is not a reliable clue, as it may have been either someone‚Äôs guess or a deliberate cover story. Other candidates for Hans‚Äô paternity cannot be ruled out‚Äîincluding Schimmelmann himself.
Little Hans spent his early childhood at the Schimmelmanns‚Äô sugar plantation, Constitution Hill, picking up three languages used locally (Danish, English, and the St. Croix creole of the time). In 1788, Schimmelmann left his post in the Danish West Indies, and he and Henrietta made arrangements to return to Copenhagen and settle in an affluent neighbourhood. They selected several adult slaves to take back to the homeland‚Äîincluding Hans‚Äôs mother, now called Emilia Regina after a mandatory baptism in 1787, and her brother. The slave children were another matter. They were considered too young to bother with, so four-year-old Hans, along with his younger half-sister and their two cousins, were left behind in Christiansted. Surprisingly, four years later, the Schimmelmanns appear to have changed their minds; they arranged for the two eight-year-olds‚ÄîHans and one of his cousins‚Äîto travel to Copenhagen and join the household in 1792.
Europe was another world relative to St. Croix, and not just because it was colder. The languages were mostly familiar, but the capital of Denmark was large, bustling, and cosmopolitan‚Äîhome to almost 100,000 people from a variety of backgrounds. Far removed from the sugar plantation, here all of the slaves were house-slaves; they were responsible for looking after the Schimmelmanns‚Äô children, and cleaning and maintaining the family‚Äôs lavish five-storey mansion to the standards of European aristocrats.
Ludvig Schimmelmann died at the end of 1793; most of his surviving children moved out in their young adulthood before the end of the century. Now the head of household, Henrietta Schimmelmann made it very evident that she believed in the traditional definition of slavery, whereby her slaves would do her bidding and that was that. The Copenhagen census of 1801 lists that she had nine ‚Äúservants‚Äù at the time, including Hans, his mother, and his cousin. Hans was given a small amount of schooling‚Äîenough to learn to read and write and do arithmetic, which suited Hans‚Äôs curiosity and intellect. Alongside this, he received exposure to European music and fell in love with playing the violin. At some point, he was able to acquire an instrument of his own, which he cherished. Once he was a teenager, he was to some extent allowed to roam the city on his own. Still, he and the few other Black house-slaves of Copenhagen did not have true freedom, nor would it have readily occurred to their owners to consider giving it to them.
More broadly, across Europe slavery was becoming a contentious political issue. Abolitionist thought was on the rise, with an increasing number of people scoffing at defenders‚Äô insistence that slaves were happy (or, if unhappy, it was their own fault). Denmark agreed in 1792 that it would soon put a stop to new slave trading; however, this would not end any pre-existing slavery. In order to mitigate the inconvenience to angry wealthy white people, the changes would take effect only in stages over several years. In 1795, it became illegal for Danish slaveholders to transport Caribbean slaves back to Denmark (as the Schimmelmanns had done). In 1803, slave trading beyond the Danish West Indies was outlawed.
But none of this freed Hans Jonathan. As the 18th century turned into the 19th, he found himself in a rotten state indeed, and started pushing back against his lot in life. He repeatedly broke his evening curfew, spending time in the city and mingling with locals, visitors, and students studying in Copenhagen. This infuriated Henrietta. She would stay up waiting for him, then lecture him when he finally returned. Henrietta was a well-off, powerful woman with allies throughout the upper ranks of Danish society. She had no trouble putting her foot down to rein in a disobedient teenage slave.
Things reached their breaking-point at the beginning of 1801 when greater hostilities flared and Denmark found itself on the brink of war with the United Kingdom. Normally these two countries got along with each other, but that was mainly because Denmark tended to be wary and deferential. The British as a colonial and trading power were brash, dominant, heavy-handed, and hypercompetitive. They were especially interested in keeping war supplies out of the hands of their most dependable adversaries‚Äîthe French. So when Denmark sought to enter into an alliance with Russia, Sweden, and Prussia to facilitate trade with France, it flung British hackles into the stratosphere. Enraged, Great Britain intercepted a group of Danish trading ships, setting the scene for direct naval conflict. Up against the most powerful navy on the planet, Denmark put out a call for patriotic men to enlist.
Henrietta Schimmelmann‚Äôs 20-year-old son enthusiastically took up the call and went to serve in the Royal Danish Navy. Right behind him was a similarly eager 16-year-old Hans Jonathan‚Äîuntil Henrietta caught him and said absolutely not. Hans argued that he did not have to follow her rules. Appalled, Henrietta reached for a cane and whacked the young man with it several times to show him who was boss. That did it. Later that evening, Hans said a quick goodbye to his mother, then walked off the Schimmelmann property and joined the Navy anyway.
Henrietta went to the police. Her son had spoken to them just two days prior, reporting the disappearance of money from his possession‚Äî200 Danish rigsdalers (several thousand dollars in modern USD). There is no evidence that this had anything to do with Hans Jonathan, but Henrietta decided to blame her slave for it anyway‚Äîon top of complaining about his running away. This move was a gamble that could soon have turned very dark, as theft in Denmark had frequently been treated as a capital offense. Henrietta emphasised that the punishment she sought was merely to have Hans Jonathan sent back to St. Croix and sold. That would put him in his place‚Äîliterally and otherwise.
Meanwhile, the newly minted naval recruit was about to help his current country face the British. It was the beginning of April, and Britain was eager to catch Danish ships in port at Copenhagen as early as possible. Any later in the spring, and the ice would melt enough to risk letting the Russians out to assist Denmark. In Copenhagen, the Danes would have the home-field advantage, but that was all that could be said for them, as their fleet was much smaller than the British Royal Navy and not remotely as well-trained.
The Danish people tended to be quiet about their devotion to their country, but when the Battle of Copenhagen began on 2 April 1801, Denmark found itself whipped into a fiery patriotic frenzy. Hans Jonathan was assigned to the Charlotte Amalie, a ship named after a queen consort from a century earlier. The ship took the not-quite-17-year-old and his shipmates straight to the heart of the action. Barely 300 metres from two huge British ships, the Charlotte Amalie exchanged fire with the British over the course of a harrowing four hours, as the doctors below the deck of the ship desperately tried to keep up with the number of men being wounded or worse. The Danish navy did get a boost from Copenhagen‚Äôs narrow harbour, which was difficult for the large British vessels to navigate; Britain briefly wavered and considered retreating, but then regained the upper hand. With British victory inevitable, British Vice-Admiral Horatio Nelson sent a letter to Danish Crown Prince Frederick proposing a ceasefire‚Äîthe acceptance of which, he added, would keep him from having to set fire to the captured Danish ships with the crews still inside. Frederick accepted, ending the Battle of Copenhagen and kick-starting negotiations between the two countries.
The Charlotte Amalie was battered and had lost about one-sixth of its men. But Hans Jonathan was uninjured, plus his captain noticed his resolve and praised him specifically in front of others. On top of that, the Navy paid the young man 15 Danish rigsdalers for his service in battle (between $200 and $300 in modern USD).
Hans Jonathan probably thought that in joining the Navy against Henrietta Schimmelmann‚Äôs wishes, he had made his point. After all, he had risked his life‚Äîand perhaps secured a future for himself as a Danish naval officer instead of a slave. It had been only days since the Battle of Copenhagen, but, assuming that Henrietta had given up, Hans went home to see his mother.
Henrietta had done no such thing. The police had paid little attention to her complaint‚Äîthe imminent British threat to the city had been somewhat more pressing. Without reinforcement, Henrietta created a makeshift jail by locking Hans inside the Schimmelmanns‚Äô property. But after a couple of days she decided that she‚Äôd had enough, and released him back to the Royal Danish Navy.
The Navy briefly assigned Hans to a ship called the Denmark, where he forthrightly shared his unusual story with Captain Steen Andersen Bille. Subsequently, reassigned to the Elephant, Hans met a man much like himself: a slave named Peter Samuel who had also just served in the Battle of Copenhagen. Unlike Hans, Peter was in the Navy at the insistence of his owner. Still, the men had a shared goal in securing their freedom. Fortunately, they had an influential ally in Hans‚Äôs previous captain. Bille was a thoughtful man who had spent time in the Danish West Indies and was sympathetic to the two men‚Äôs cause. Better yet, he was so well-respected in the Danish government that he could simply take the issue directly to Crown Prince Frederick‚Äîwhich he did.
As biographer P√°lsson points out, this was a dilemma for Frederick, who knew both Steen Bille and Henrietta Schimmelmann well, and was now caught between them in a dispute. Taking either position on the issue of the promising young naval recruit who was also a runaway slave could have amounted to a betrayal.
Frederick considered. Possibly in the spirit of Europe‚Äôs encroaching doubt about slavery, he ended up writing a very cautiously worded, three-page letter to Bille on 12 May 1801, gently arguing that on homeland Danish soil, the only people who could be convincingly argued to be legally slaves were prisoners whose sentences specified servitude. As long as Henrietta Schimmelmann was located within Denmark proper, he continued, no one in her household could qualify as anything lower than a free servant. While the letter did not name Hans Jonathan specifically as the person who ‚Äúis considered free and enjoys rights‚Äù, it did refer to Henrietta Schimmelmann, so the intended referent was unambiguous.
It was more than enough for Captain Steen Bille. On 14 May, Bille officially bestowed freedom on Hans Jonathan. From a different commanding officer, but as the result of the same letter from Crown Prince Frederick, his shipmate Peter Samuel received the same. Finally free at 17, Hans Jonathan rented a room above a tavern, filled it with his possessions including the beloved violin, and began to consider how to pursue the life of his own that he had sought for so long.
The development left Henrietta Schimmelmann newly irate. Only a handful of people had seen Frederick‚Äôs letter to Bille, and it is not clear if Henrietta was among them; either way, the consequences would have allowed her to infer a major risk to her ability to maintain her household the way she wanted it. The letter was, from this perspective, a dangerous precedent. On its basis, any of the other eight slaves in her household (including Hans Jonathan‚Äôs mother, uncle, and cousin) could simply walk away with the presumed blessing of Denmark‚Äôs very ruler. Unacceptable! On 19 May‚Äîonly a week after the release of Frederick‚Äôs letter‚ÄîHenrietta marched straight back into the same police station as before and submitted a formal written complaint, asking the authorities to arrest and question Hans Jonathan.
This time, the police officers went out looking for Hans. Finding him at the tavern, they explained the issue. Hans told them he wanted to serve the Danish monarch by remaining in the navy‚Äîand he told the police that he would provide evidence of having been set free.
The complaint was left to be resolved by the courts, but when the case came up in front of the judges, Henrietta Schimmelmann was not in attendance. She had vowed to send relevant documents via her intermediary‚Äîher steward Peder Hansen‚Äîbut when Hansen arrived, he claimed to have no documents to show. The court threw out the case, and Hans Jonathan was free once again. But Henrietta had not given up. She went to the navy and requested 400 rigsdalers as compensation for losing her slave (somewhere between $5,000 and $7,000 in modern USD). The Navy brushed her off.
A badly timed coincidence gave her a new idea. On 20 July 1801, a slave named David Tams slipped away from his rural Danish household and made a wild dash for Copenhagen. He too was from St. Croix and had been brought back to the homeland by slaveowners. However, his attempt at entering the city got him arrested. Tams‚Äôs irritated owner then opened a civil lawsuit hoping to establish a legal claim on the man‚Äîand Henrietta Schimmelmann, bringing a whole new meaning to the term ‚Äúfollow suit,‚Äù decided to do the same. Legally, this was much less complicated than her earlier accusations of theft and desertion; if she won the civil case, it would simply establish that she owned Hans Jonathan, end of story.
It was not obvious how this new court case would go. On the one hand, bringing slaves from the Danish West Indies to Denmark itself had been technically illegal since 1795. On the other, Hans Jonathan had arrived in Denmark before that point, and his move to Copenhagen had not automatically voided his status as a slave. If Henrietta owned him, she should still have the right to sell him. With that, on the evening of 3 December 1801, four police officers set off for the tavern to arrest Hans Jonathan‚Äîwho once again explained the existence of the letter from Crown Prince Frederick to Captain Steen Bille ensuring his freedom. The police officers were unmoved. A slave with a personal letter from the Crown Prince of Denmark? Suuuure. Within an hour, Hans was in a cell.
At the time, Danish courtroom processes were conducted slowly and mainly through written statements. However, then, as now, access to skilled legal assistance was not equitable. Henrietta Schimmelmann, wealthy and connected, had a steadfast lawyer named N. C. Bierring, and he did so much of the work that there is no evidence she ever made an appearance in court herself. At the other end of the scale, Hans Jonathan was unable to afford the services of any lawyer, and was assigned an attorney by the court, a man thought to be named ‚ÄòBeyer‚Äô (though sources do not agree).
Bierring slammed Hans Jonathan for his (supposed) shameless lying‚Äîto think that a slave could have had the backing of the Danish crown prince! Captain Bille still had the copy of the letter from Crown Prince Frederick, and either way could have established the truth if called as a witness. However, for some reason, Beyer did not call Bille, which suggests some incompetence as it left the accusation of lying unchallenged. Beyer also made a few errors in recounting the facts of the case, and at one point lapsed into sarcasm. Bierring leapt at the chance to criticise Beyer‚Äôs tone, undercutting the inconvenient fact that some of Beyer‚Äôs arguments had merit and strength. For instance, Beyer had been through the Danish legal code and found absolutely no support for slavery in homeland Denmark. Also, had Henrietta Schimmelmann not said in her written statement to police that Hans Jonathan had ‚Äúleft her service‚Äù‚Äîand thus never been anything less than a servant?
Every single one of the witnesses was from Henrietta Schimmelmann‚Äôs household, and meant to support the plaintiff. However, they were less than cooperative. Emilia Regina was understandably unhelpful when it came to answering questions in a case against her own son (especially with her own freedom possibly being at stake as well). Likewise, Henrietta‚Äôs steward Peder Hansen stood up for Hans Jonathan and pointed out that Henrietta had physically beaten him ‚Äúa few times with a Spanish stick‚Äù and that Hans had left in order to serve his country. Beyer also asked: who was the young man‚Äôs father, anyway? A ‚Äúfree white man‚Äù or a slave? Presumably the idea was to explore the possibility that Henrietta Schimmelmann‚Äôs claim on Hans Jonathan was far from watertight‚Äîbut the judges accepted Bierring‚Äôs objection of ‚Äúirrelevant‚Äù and refused to let Emilia Regina respond.
Toward the end of May 1802, the analogous case of David Tams wrapped up‚ÄîDanish judges sided with the man‚Äôs owner. For Hans Jonathan only days later, the judges likewise announced on 31 May their decision that Hans Jonathan was Henrietta Schimmelmann‚Äôs property and she was legally permitted to send him back to the Danish West Indies to be sold. Four of the judges saw no room for argument. The fifth, a young man not much older than Hans himself, ended up siding with his seniors but also made room in his comments for a dissenting argument that Caribbean slaves arriving on Danish soil could only be servants rather than slaves‚Äîprecisely the conclusion that Crown Prince Frederick had drawn in his not-at-all-fictional letter.
The courts had not found Hans guilty of any crime, but unless he chose to appeal the verdict, he was required to turn himself in to Henrietta Schimmelmann within 15 days. The court does not seem to have noticed that, as a strategy for containing a runaway, this plan left something to be desired.
In the days following the verdict, a summary of the case and its outcome were published and disseminated as usual to the people of Copenhagen‚Äîthus making very public the dispute between the socialite and the escaped slave. One Danish government official even wrote to the Danish West Indies to warn them that an ill-behaved man named Hans Jonathan might soon be sold on the island. For the social elite, the details of the civil lawsuit made for irresistible gossip, to the point that it may have become a problem for Henrietta Schimmelmann in spite of her nominal victory.
Hans Jonathan did not request an appeal. He also did not surrender himself to Henrietta Schimmelmann. He was nowhere to be found. Once the 15-day period had elapsed, Henrietta gained the legal right to have him located and arrested. However, she does not seem to have requested police assistance. Instead, within only a year, she moved her household out of the city altogether.
However one-sided, the case was enough of a landmark that the story of the young biracial Black man up against a crushing system remains fairly well-known in Danish legal circles. But the man himself had apparently walked out of the courtroom and into the streets of Copenhagen and vanished. Even more than 150 years later, a comprehensive 1964 article by Danish law professor Knud Waaben would point out that historians had no idea what had become of David Tams and Hans Jonathan.
Around 2003, a handful of Icelanders found the 1964 Knud Waaben article. One of them reached out to Waaben, suggesting the possibility that Hans J√≥natan‚Äîthe Caribbean-born ancestor who had arrived in Dj√∫pivogur with the Danish trading ships‚Äîwas the same Hans Jonathan who had faced the punitive Danish legal system only very slightly earlier. All of the pieces fit, and Hans J√≥natan‚Äôs backstory filled in the missing history.
Shortly after the 1802 verdict was read, Hans Jonathan briefly and surreptitiously stopped by Henrietta Schimmelmann‚Äôs house to gather his possessions, including the treasured violin, and say goodbye to his mother.
At the time, the Danish empire included both Norway and Iceland. While Norway was a powerhouse on the level of Denmark itself, Iceland was heavily agrarian and deep in the clutches of its colonial overlords. In 1800, the island‚Äôs 50,000 people were split between so many individual farms and tiny rural towns that even the largest settlement, Reykjav√≠k, had a population of no more than 300. While Iceland had its own history, its own language, and its own literary tradition, Denmark had it in a stranglehold. The Danish essentially maintained a monopoly on trade with Iceland, forbidding the locals from trading with anyone else, and often treated the island like a pesky dependent child.
It was around the end of June 1802‚Äîjust after the northern ice had melted for the summer‚Äîthat one of the usual Danish trade-ships docked at the town of Dj√∫pivogur along the eastern fjords of Iceland and Hans Jonathan stepped off. The journey had taken about two weeks. It is not known whether Hans chose this location specifically, or simply decided to leave Copenhagen for any reasonably far-flung destination as soon as he could. It is also unclear whether he intended to stay in Dj√∫pivogur or to keep moving around as needed. Perhaps, in the manner of a talented musician, he played it by ear.
At least he could ask around for opportunities at his destination right away. Dj√∫pivogur, population approximately 100, had sprung up as a trading post, and as a result a number of the locals spoke Danish as well as Icelandic.
None of them would have been at all familiar with the sight of a Black man, even a light-skinned biracial Black man. Fortunately, the locals welcomed him without xenophobia. They likely thought of him as the sort of Danish man they were familiar with: a merchant. Which, in fact, is what he soon became. Almost immediately following his arrival in Dj√∫pivogur, Hans met the manager of the town‚Äôs general store, J√≥n Stef√°nsson, and was hired as an assistant.
Stef√°nsson was known for his kindness towards Dj√∫pivogur‚Äôs townspeople and its very few visitors. He was a businessman but also a songwriter of local renown, not to mention an enthusiastic collector and lender of books. To Hans, Stef√°nsson soon proved to be a key mentor and a close friend. Stef√°nsson was Icelandic, but he spoke Danish as well; his wife was also from Denmark.
Icelandic census records accurately list Hans Jonathan‚Äôs name, profession, and birthplace‚Äîsuggesting that he was honest about his origins and background, perhaps due to having quickly established trust with the people of Dj√∫pivogur. However, he must have weighed the risks while deciding what to tell his new neighbours. With so many Danes around, word could conceivably have reached the relentless Henrietta Schimmelmann. On the other hand, especially once he became a trained businessman, Hans may also have been aware that the costs of retrieving an errant slave from so far away would not have been profitable. Besides, by 1807, Denmark was busy contending with a resurgent United Kingdom, leading to a Second Battle of Copenhagen and its humiliating aftermath (including British occupation of the Danish West Indies). A missing slave was not high on anyone‚Äôs priority list.
By 1809, on a sparsely populated island where the Atlantic slave-trade was not likely to be on many people‚Äôs radar, J√≥n Stef√°nsson translated fiery abolitionist essays from Danish into Icelandic. It is probable that this project sprang from discussions that Stefansson was having with his assistant.
Hans had found a niche for himself in every respect. As a young assistant storekeeper, he gained a reputation as a stellar record-keeper, committed to both accuracy and integrity. Some of his records from the Dj√∫pivogur store survive, in tidy Danish-style handwriting. The local oral history preserved tales of Hans Jonathan‚Äôs insistence on rectifying accounting errors regardless of who was in the wrong. He gave generously of his time, sharing practical skills related to everything from mathematics to construction to wayfinding. Another of his routine duties was helping visitors to Dj√∫pivogur navigate the harsh local terrain. A Norwegian surveyor, a Scottish preacher, and a Danish friend of the Stef√°nssons‚Äô all ended up mentioning Hans Jonathan by name in their memoirs.
He was never a wealthy man in Iceland‚Äînever a landowner, in a place where virtually everyone else was. But he had his freedom and enough to live on, and he consistently spoke up for the rights and wellbeing of those less fortunate. It is uncertain whether he learned in 1816 that Henrietta Schimmelmann had died. Back in Denmark, he may have been close enough to her children to infer that they did not share their mother‚Äôs keen interest in owning slaves. At any rate, from that point onwards, no one would be chasing Hans Jonathan with a metaphorical net.
A few years later, the storekeeper J√≥n Stef√°nsson contracted a serious illness, and died in 1819. A Danish mercantile company bought the store and put 35-year-old Hans Jonathan in charge. Around the same time, romantic sparks developed: he and a 21-year-old woman named Katr√≠n Anton√≠usd√≥ttir caught each other‚Äôs attention. She came from a farming family based near Dj√∫pivogur, and was a hard-working, skilled, well-liked member of the community. On 28 February 1820, they were married in a local church; the catering was provided by J√≥n Stef√°nsson‚Äôs widow Ellen Katr√≠n.
To this day, the general practice in Iceland is for children‚Äôs second names to be based on the first name of one of the parents; nearly everyone is ‚Äòson of X‚Äô, ‚Äòdaughter of Y‚Äô, or ‚Äòchild of Z‚Äô. In other words, it did not matter that Hans Jonathan had never had a mainland-European-style family surname in the first place. However, he and his wife decided to treat Hans‚Äôs second name like a surname anyway, and to pass it along to their children. Ludvik Stefan Jonathan was born on 26 May 1821, and Hansina Regina Jonathan followed on 4 August 1824.
In between the arrivals of the children, however, the store at Dj√∫pivogur ran into financial trouble. Hans could not stand the sight of poverty and ended up putting the store in debt in order to assist the locals who were struggling the most. In 1823, he left his job and moved his family to a rental farm. This was a small and undistinguished property, but the couple‚Äôs combined skills‚ÄîKatr√≠n having grown up on a farm twice the size‚Äîallowed them to carve out a life there. Records of the family‚Äôs possessions attest to music-making, ice-skating, and book-reading alongside everyday farmwork.
But Hans‚Äôs former employer remained suspicious of him. In 1827, the new store managers concluded that some grain was missing from storage, and asked whether he knew anything about this. The issue never received a resolution. While out in the fields, 43-year-old Hans Jonathan died suddenly of what was probably a cerebral hemorrhage. Given that his family was only renting the farm at Borgargar√∞ur, Katr√≠n had him buried at her own family‚Äôs farm in nearby Hals. However, as headstones were very expensive, the exact location of his grave is not known.
Many of Hans‚Äôs assets were liquidated to settle the outstanding debts‚Äîthough his beloved violin went to his son Ludvik. Katr√≠n likely continued running the farm at Borgargar√∞ur and raising the children on her own, at least until she remarried in about 1834 and the family moved to the town of Bulandnes several years later. Ludvik and Hansina both married and started families of their own, but then both died in their 30s. Fortunately, Katr√≠n lived until 1869, which was long enough to finish raising her six surviving grandchildren and see them all become locally well-respected young adults.
Slavery was finally abolished in the Danish West Indies in 1848, though the system of bound servitude that replaced it was not much better. Only the decline of the sugarcane industry finally brought it all crashing down. In 1917, with the plantation era behind and the colony becoming a financial burden, Denmark sold the Danish West Indies to the United States, which paid $25 million and renamed the territory the U.S. Virgin Islands. Its capital on the island of St. Thomas is still named Charlotte Amalie. As for Iceland, it finally gained full independence from Denmark in 1944, and Reykjav√≠k has become a city of more than 100,000 people.
Over a century later, in the 1990s, Dr. K√°ri Stef√°nsson did not set out to investigate Hans J√≥natan‚Äôs genetic history. Instead, he became a neurologist, and moved to the United States to complete his training at the University of Chicago, then on to Harvard University to teach. But Stef√°nsson found himself repeatedly thinking of the untapped scientific potential of mapping and studying the gene pool in his home country.
Stef√°nsson realised that Iceland‚Äôs genetic homogeneity could make it a spectacular natural laboratory. While the combination of a small founding population and a low number of newcomers would not eliminate random mutations in the genome over time, it would certainly control for genetic variance between humans to an unusual degree. One of Stef√°nsson‚Äôs earliest ideas along these lines, for instance, proposed comparing the genetic material of Icelanders with and without multiple sclerosis (MS). Given extremely similar ancestry, the DNA of these two groups would be overwhelmingly comparable. If such a study identified a tiny number of systematic differences between the individuals with MS and those without, those differences would be candidates for the genetic origins of MS in humans more generally. The study would be all the better for taking place in a country with universal health care and‚Äîcharacteristically‚Äîextensive medical record-keeping.
By 1996, the chance to launch an enormous Icelandic genome project was too tempting to pass up. Stef√°nsson resigned his position as Chief of Neuropathology at Harvard and moved back to Iceland to establish deCODE Genetics. While deCODE was always a private biopharmaceutical company, and there are privacy concerns in the collection of health-related information, many Icelanders have been willing to provide consent. The number represented in the data held by deCODE is now well above two-thirds of the adult population of the country‚Äîand the findings have been unlike anything else in the world. Aside from identifying markers of susceptibility to particular genetic diseases, the findings have yielded high-resolution models of the human genome, inspired new drug development, and illuminated several aspects of how genes recombine in human offspring.
In the last decade, with new scholarly attention from multiple angles, the full story of Hans Jonathan finally came together. University of Iceland history professor G√≠sli P√°lsson published a full biography of Hans in Icelandic in 2014, with an English translation by Anna Yates (The Man Who Stole Himself) following in 2016.
Meanwhile, deCODE undertook another milestone. Remembering the stories of his youth about the Black ancestor in his father‚Äôs hometown of Dj√∫pivogur, Stef√°nsson started a project with several colleagues to reassemble the man‚Äôs genome from the genetic information in his descendants alone. What made the task straightforward was that the signal of any recent African ancestry would be clear against the backdrop of the limited Nordic/Celtic gene pool that had characterised Iceland for 1,200 years. In their 2018 paper, the researchers verified that the only noticeable source of recent African DNA in the Icelandic gene-pool in the fifty years between 1880 and 1930 had come from only one individual with XY sex chromosomes: Hans J√≥natan. His Y chromosome, inherited from his father, was typical of mainland Europe; his X chromosome, from his mother, was clearly African in origin.
A number of Hans Jonathan and Katr√≠n Anton√≠usd√≥ttir‚Äôs descendants have been noted musicians, and great-granddaughter Hans√≠na Reg√≠na Bj√∂rnsd√≥ttir was a well-known early photographer in the late 19th century. By the 2010s, the genetic researchers who collaborated on the 2018 paper‚Äî17 geneticists including K√°ri Stef√°nsson himself‚Äîfound 788 verified living descendants. They partially sequenced the genomes of 182 of these descendants, then for 20 of those, the researchers sequenced their genomes in their entirety. While no single descendant could have inherited all or even most of Hans Jonathan‚Äôs DNA, different descendants got different pieces and combinations, and with the influence of the baseline Icelandic gene-pool (i.e. Katr√≠n) filtered out, Hans‚Äôs genes from elsewhere have been revealed. While the identity of Hans Jonathan‚Äôs ‚Äúfree white man‚Äù father has not yet been determined, the researchers have found considerable insight in an analysis of Hans‚Äôs maternal DNA.
We know very little about Emilia Regina‚Äôs background from the historical record alone. Emilia Regina appears to have been born around 1760, possibly the daughter of one of three house-slaves at a sugar plantation called ‚ÄúLa Reine‚Äù, but it is not even clear whether she was born on St. Croix or transported there from Africa at a young age. After Henrietta Schimmelmann‚Äôs 1802 civil lawsuit, Emilia Regina disappears from the record entirely.
In 2017, Denmark issued a formal apology for the role it played in the European slave-trade. Modern genetics cannot possibly compensate for the harm done, but it can offer some answers after-the-fact and help descendants and their supporters put some of the pieces back together.
The researchers on the 2018 paper zeroed in on Hans Jonathan‚Äôs maternal haploid genome‚Äîhis DNA from Emilia Regina‚Äîand reported having been able to reassemble about 38 percent of it. This is a stunning amount of information gathered from modern descendants alone about the mother of a man who died in 1827. Comparing the DNA to reference populations from different parts of the African continent, the geneticists found that Emilia Regina was clearly linked with present-day populations of Nigeria, Cameroon, and Benin‚Äîparticularly those of Yoruba descent. In reverse-engineering the DNA of a group of present-day descendants to make new discoveries about ancestors from centuries ago, this case study is the first of its kind.
To be sure, the unusual circumstances of Hans Jonathan‚Äôs background, in conjunction with his excellent choice of hiding place and the large number of descendants he has, all ensured that this was a relatively clear-cut demonstration of how the DNA of a single ancestor could be disentangled from everything else going on in a population‚Äôs collective genes. Still, it is a leap forward for human understanding. Centuries ago, slaves in the Americas abducted from Africa frequently hoped that they would be able to someday return. On the individual level, extremely few were able to do so; however, genetic genealogy opens up the possibility of making reconnections to bridge the gaping hole.
As the editors of Nature Genetics commented in a short editorial accompanying the release of the 2018 article on the background of Hans Jonathan, the project crucially involves ‚Äúour interwoven genomic and social histories.‚Äù In other words, DNA is something of a time-capsule of all of our biological ancestors. To the extent that we are our genes, we are also the histories of those who came before us ‚Äì just as our own histories will be interwoven with those to come.

Medieval Monks Wrote Over a Copy of an Ancient Star Catalog. Now, a Particle Accelerator is Revealing the Long-Lost Original Text
The parchments initially contained references to a star catalog and maps created during the second century B.C.E.
A little more than a thousand years ago, monks at Saint Catherine‚Äôs Monastery in Egypt‚Äôs Sinai desert removed Western Palestinian Aramaic and Greek writing from animal-skin parchments. They replaced the words with a Syriac translation of writings by John Climacus, also known as Saint John of the Ladder.
The monks had created something called a palimpsest‚Äîa text whose original writing was mostly erased to make room for new work‚Äînamed the Codex Climaci Rescriptus. Parchments were extremely expensive at the time, so reusing pieces was common practice.
The original text, however, might not be completely lost. That‚Äôs good news, because it seems to contain copied portions of a second-century B.C.E. star catalog with maps originally created by the Greek astronomer Hipparchus, known as the ‚Äúfather of scientific astronomy.‚Äù Researchers are now using a type of particle accelerator at the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory to uncover the hidden words.
‚ÄúX-ray beams from our synchrotron at SLAC are helping uncover the long-erased and overwritten star map by scanning for trace metals left behind by the original inks,‚Äù reads a SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory social media post.
Previous work has revealed that many pages of the Codex Climaci Rescriptus come from a fifth- or sixth-century C.E. book, which included a copy of an astronomical poem titled Phaenomen. It was originally written by the Greek poet Aratus in the third century B.C.E. Alongside the poem appear to be transcriptions from Hipparchus‚Äô star catalog, which was completed around 129 B.C.E. The work represents the ‚Äúearliest known attempt to record accurate coordinates of many celestial objects observable with the naked eye,‚Äù researchers wrote in a 2022 study investigating the Codex Climaci Rescriptus‚Äô original writings.
Little of Hipparchus‚Äô work, which he likely documented on papyrus, has endured the test of time. So, researchers often rely on the writings of later authors to investigate the Greek astronomer. His few known stellar coordinates have reached modern-day scholars through a Latin translation of Aratus‚Äô poems and related texts, according to the study.
Did you know? Hipparchus‚Äô history
Hipparchus was born in Nicaea, which is located in modern-day Turkey. He made advancements in trigonometry and approached astronomy as a mathematical science. He spent much of his adult life observing the night sky and conducting research on the island of Rhodes in Greece.
Last month, researchers at SLAC began scanning 11 pages of the codex, which were sent to the laboratory in Menlo Park, California, by the Museum of the Bible in Washington, D.C., reports KQED‚Äôs Ayah Ali-Ahmad. The facility‚Äôs synchrotron lightsource instrument can produce intense X-ray beams that can unveil the document‚Äôs hidden text based on the ink composition, which differs from that used by the monks. The work has already revealed the ancient Greek word for ‚ÄúAquarius‚Äù and details about stars within the constellation, Victor Gysembergh, a historian of science at the French National Center for Scientific Research who is leading the project, tells the outlet.
‚ÄúThe goal is to recover as many of these coordinates as possible,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThis will help us answer some of the biggest questions on the birth of science: Why did they start doing science 2,000 and more years ago? How did they get so good at it so fast? Because the coordinates we are finding are incredibly accurate for something that is done with the naked eye.‚Äù
The scribe who copied Phaenomena, which details how various constellations rise and set, onto the parchment integrated descriptions of the stars‚Äô positions that were probably based on Hipparchus‚Äô work. The celestial objects‚Äô coordinate system and accuracy align with references to the ancient astronomer‚Äôs writings, reports Science News‚Äô Adam Mann. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an appendix which includes coordinates of the stars discussed in the poem, and then little sketches of the star maps,‚Äù Minhal Gardezi, a physicist at the University of Wisconsin‚ÄìMadison who is working on the project, tells the outlet.
Bradley Schaefer, a historian of astronomy at Louisiana State University who isn‚Äôt involved in the work, tells Scientific American‚Äôs K. R. Callaway that the unveiled text might shed light on enduring questions on if later astronomers, including Ptolemy, were recording their own observations or partly assembling earlier work made by others.
‚ÄúWho knows what the star chart study will show?‚Äù Graham George, a chemist at the University of Saskatchewan in Canada who also isn‚Äôt involved in the new research, says to Science News. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt wait to find out.‚Äù

articles.content:
A Smithsonian magazine special report
Historians Thought This Rare Renaissance Portrait by One of the First Famous Female Artists Was Lost to History‚ÄîUntil It Surfaced in North Carolina
Sofonisba Anguissola‚Äôs 16th-century painting of a clergyman was known only through a black-and-white photo. However, the original had been hiding in a private collection in North Carolina since 1977
A long-lost painting by Sofonisba Anguissola‚Äîone of the few famous women artists of the Renaissance‚Äîhas resurfaced in New York City. Her Portrait of a Canon Regular, painted in 1552, was recently displayed at the Winter Show, marking its first time on public view.
Portrait of a Canon Regular depicts an unidentified clergy member mid-lecture. His right hand touches the pages of a Bible, open to the Gospel of John. An eagle, a symbol of St. John, holds the book aloft in its talons, ‚Äúhovering somewhat menacingly in the dark,‚Äù per a statement from Robert Simon Fine Art, the gallery that presented the piece.
Anguissola ‚Äúworked with deeper study and greater grace than any woman of our times at problems of design,‚Äù wrote the 16th-century Renaissance artist and biographer Giorgio Vasari. ‚ÄúFor not only has she learned to draw, paint and copy from nature, and reproduce most skillfully works by other artists, but she has on her own painted some most rare and beautiful paintings.‚Äù
Portrait of a Canon Regular made its debut at the Winter Show, an art fair held at the Park Avenue Armory on the Upper East Side. The painting was presented with a price tag of $450,000, reports Artnet‚Äôs Eileen Kinsella. According to the gallery, the canvas is one of fewer than 20 signed paintings by Anguissola that survive today.
Until recently, Portrait of a Canon Regular was thought to be lost. The Frick Art Reference Library had a black-and-white photo of it dated to the 1920s, but the trail stopped there, reports Artnet. Then, in 2024, art historian Michael Cole, author of the book Sofonisba‚Äôs Lesson, gave a lecture about Anguissola at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. The talk was posted on YouTube.
Fortunately, the owners of the original painting, based in Durham, North Carolina, watched the lecture. They had inherited the piece from their relatives, who had purchased it at a North Carolina auction in 1977.
‚ÄúI was initially approached to value the painting and to consult on its conservation, provenance and proper framing,‚Äù art dealer Robert Simon tells Artnet. ‚ÄúIn the end, the owners decided to sell the painting, and I am acting as their agent in bringing it to a wider audience.‚Äù
Anguissola was born in Cremona, Italy, around 1532. Encouraged by her father, she began artistic training as a teenager and quickly showed promise. Her early work was even praised by Michelangelo, who corresponded with her father. Anguissola painted Portrait of a Canon Regular when she was around 20; the portrait is her earliest signed and dated piece.
Fun fact: Sofonisba Anguissola‚Äôs early work
Michelangelo complimented Anguissola‚Äôs portrayal of a young child in Boy Bitten by a Crayfish (circa 1554), according to the National Museum of Women in the Arts.
By the late 1550s, Anguissola‚Äôs artistic reputation had extended beyond Italy. In 1559, the king of Spain, Philip II, asked her to be a lady-in-waiting to his third wife, Elisabeth of Valois. Anguissola lived in the Spanish court for 14 years, painting portraits of the royal family, teaching the queen to draw and caring for children. After marrying the brother of the Viceroy of Sicily, she moved to the Italian island, where she would live until her death in 1625.
‚ÄúSofonisba wasn‚Äôt just anybody,‚Äù Salvatore Patane, a Sicilian priest, told the London Times‚Äô Julia Buckley in November 2025. Anguissola lived in Patane‚Äôs town, Paterno, which recently held a celebration of the artist. ‚ÄúShe was a woman who managed to leave home and go to the most important court of the time,‚Äù he added.
Anguissola‚Äôs position in the Spanish court provided security and status, but its strict artistic standards tamped down her creativity, Simon tells the Art Newspaper‚Äôs Carlie Porterfield. ‚ÄúIn Spain, every portrait had to look kind of alike, so she lost a lot of the inventiveness,‚Äù he says.
As such, Anguissola‚Äôs earlier work from Italy‚Äî‚Äúher brilliant portraits of the 1550s‚Äù‚Äîare highly valued, Simon tells Artnet. Per the Times, Vasari wrote that Anguissola‚Äôs portraits were ‚Äúdone so well that they appear to breathe.‚Äù
Anguissola produced many detailed portraits of herself, royals, nobles and several clergymen. On the desk before the subject of Portrait of a Canon Regular is a Turkish carpet, ‚Äúa preferred device of the artist that is found in several variations in her works,‚Äù Simon tells Artnet. The portrait was recently conserved, revealing her full signature: ‚ÄúSophonisba Anguissola Virgo,‚Äù followed by the date 1552.
Though Anguissola gained important recognition during her life, her artistic reputation faded over the centuries. Some of her works were misattributed. For a long time, Anguissola‚Äôs Juana of Austria and a Young Girl (1561-62) was credited to the Italian master Titian.
In recent decades, however, many exhibitions have been dedicated to Anguissola‚Äôs work. Per the National Gallery of Art, ‚ÄúShe is increasingly recognized as one of the major figures of the later Italian Renaissance.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt find a mediocre woman artist [from this time], as they would not have had a career, right?‚Äù Simon tells the Art Newspaper. ‚ÄúThey had to be really good.‚Äù

From Giant Art to Amazing Specimens, See These 20 New and Revitalized Smithsonian Shows in 2026
The Institution‚Äôs museums are commemorating America‚Äôs 250th birthday, showcasing the art of noise and displaying the best of portraiture
As the world‚Äôs largest museum group, the Smithsonian comprises 21 museums and the National Zoo. Each year, its museums unveil exhibitions that aim to educate, entertain and surprise visitors. This year brings an array of new exhibitions to the Smithsonian‚Äôs museums, exploring things like the groundbreaking designs that have influenced music history and marking the nation‚Äôs 250th anniversary. In addition, museumgoers can expect the completion of large, multiyear renovation projects at the National Air and Space Museum and the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden.
Here are 20 informative, fascinating and fun shows to look forward to in the coming year. (Dates subject to change.)
Quick facts: America 250
- As the observation of America‚Äôs 250th birthday commences, the Smithsonian is presenting a number of exhibitions and programs with the aim of ‚Äúnot only celebrating this historic event but also making it a time of reflection.‚Äù
- This year, the Smithsonian Castle will reopen from Memorial Day weekend to Labor Day with the ‚ÄúAmerican Aspirations‚Äù exhibition, the National Museum of American History will highlight 250 collection objects, the National Museum of African American History and Culture will celebrate its 10th anniversary with a block party and the National Air and Space Museum will complete its renovation for its 50th anniversary.
‚ÄúBig Things for Big Rooms‚Äù at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden
This exhibition, which opened in the closing weeks of 2025, combines rarely seen large-scale works from trailblazing artists such as Dan Flavin, Sam Gilliam, Robert Irwin, Lygia Pape and Richard Long, alongside contemporary artists whose work has expanded on the ideas of the earlier creators. Largely drawn from the Hirshhorn collection, five pieces are on view at the museum for the first time. (Through July 4, 2027)
‚ÄúAt the Vanguard: Making and Saving History at Historically Black Colleges and Universities‚Äù at the National Museum of African American History and Culture
The display includes more than 100 objects collected from five historically Black colleges and universities‚ÄîClark Atlanta University, Florida A&M University, Jackson State University, Texas Southern University and Tuskegee University‚Äîthat represent the history of the schools and tell stories of the innovations and discoveries that have enriched life for all Americans. (Through July 19, 2026)
‚ÄúHere: Pride and Belonging in African Art‚Äù at the National Museum of African Art
An exploration of LGBTQ+ artists from Africa and its diasporas, this exhibition features nearly 60 artworks, including pieces by artists Zanele Muholi, Toyin Ojih Odutola, Rotimi Fani-Kayode, Leilah Babirye and Jim Chuchu. The show celebrates intimacy, faith, family and joy as it demonstrates how these artists are part of a larger story of African art history. (Through August 23, 2026)
‚ÄúThe Outwin 2025: American Portraiture Today‚Äù at the National Portrait Gallery
The seventh triennial Outwin Boochever Portrait Competition was bumped from 2025 to 2026 due to the government the shutdown. Its 34 portraits by 35 artists were drawn from 12 states, Puerto Rico and Washington, D.C. Its first-prize $25,000 winner, Kameron Neal, will also be commissioned to portray a notable living American for the National Portrait Gallery collection. (Through August 30, 2026)
‚ÄúArt of Noise‚Äù at the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum
The art that accompanies and enhances music will be celebrated in an exhibition that includes concert posters, album cover art, photographs and the designs of digital music players and radios. Drawn from the collections of Cooper Hewitt and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, which organized the exhibition, ‚ÄúArt of Noise‚Äù will include sound installations by artist Devon Turnbull. (February 13, 2026, through August 16, 2026)
‚ÄúNick Cave: Mammoth‚Äù at the Smithsonian American Art Museum
Renowned contemporary artist Nick Cave, known for his Soundsuits series, reveals a new body of work. ‚ÄúMammoth‚Äù is an immersive exhibition showcasing the crafted hides and bones of woolly mammoths, as well as a video projection that will bring the extinct beasts to life and a beaded curtain depicting the Missouri farm where Cave grew up. As with much of his work, Cave, 66, will explore fraught American history with observations about land and race. (February 13, 2026, through January 3, 2027)
‚ÄúInto the Waters With Senju and Bingyi: Two Contemporary Paintings‚Äù at the National Museum of Asian Art
Two contemporary artists, working with grand scales, are united in their inspiration and depictions of water: Japanese painter Hiroshi Senju‚Äôs representations of waterfalls on folding screens and Chinese painter Bingyi‚Äôs three hanging scrolls of smashed ink depicting the effects of the sea breeze. (April 2, 2026, through September 27, 2026)
‚ÄúOf the Hills: Pahari Paintings From India‚Äôs Himalayan Kingdoms‚Äù at the National Museum of Asian Art
This display of paintings made for Hindu kings between the 1620s and 1830s includes works which have never been publicly shown and showcases new revelations about the artists‚Äô communities at the time. (April 18, 2026, through July 26, 2026)
‚ÄúIn Pursuit of Life, Liberty & Happiness‚Äù at the National Museum of American History
Already the home of the original Star-Spangled Banner, the museum will mark the nation‚Äôs 250th anniversary with an exhibition spanning three floors and 300,000 square feet. From its more than 1.7 million artifacts, the museum presents 250 objects to tell the country‚Äôs story, including the desk Thomas Jefferson used to draft the Declaration of Independence and the gunboat Philadelphia, the oldest surviving American Revolution fighting ship. (Opens May 14, 2026)
‚ÄúWe Make History‚Äù at the Anacostia Community Museum
The Anacostia Community Museum commemorates America‚Äôs 250th by spotlighting the importance of local history keeping and civic engagement: preserving records, creating collections and helping to craft the country‚Äôs historical narrative. (Opens May 30, 2026)
‚ÄúBison: Standing Strong‚Äù at the National Museum of Natural History
The rise, fall and return of the great American mammal is traced from ancient times to the present. The Smithsonian has a long association with the bison, as a few of them were kept in a pen outside the old Smithsonian Castle in the late 19th century. Now, the National Museum of Natural History aims to educate visitors about the animal‚Äôs past and the restoration of bison herds to the American prairie. (Opens May 2026)
‚Äú¬°Puro Ritmo! The Musical Journey of Salsa‚Äù at the National Museum of American History
Presented by the National Museum of the American Latino, this exhibition will share the rhythm, movement and heritage of salsa music in the National Museum of American History‚Äôs Molina Family Latino Gallery. The multimedia approach tells the story of salsa, noting its global impact and place alongside other music traditions. (Opens spring 2026)
‚ÄúFrom These Lands: Sharing Our Natural and Cultural Heritage‚Äù at the National Museum of Natural History
Some of the most awe-inspiring specimens and cultural items drawn from all 50 states‚Äîas well as Washington, D.C. and five inhabited territories‚Äîwill be on display to reflect the kaleidoscopic diversity of America. (Opens June 2026)
‚ÄúRTX Living in the Space Age Hall‚Äù at the National Air and Space Museum
Visitors will learn about the past, present and future of space technologies, including Earth observation systems, rockets and missiles, and how they have changed our lives. The museum presents artifacts such as a full-scale mockup of the Hubble Space Telescope and the Skylab Orbital Workshop backup. (Opens July 1, 2026)
‚ÄúJay I. Kislak World War II in the Air‚Äù at the National Air and Space Museum
This gallery explores military aviation during World War II and how aircraft transformed the nature and experience of warfare. Some never-before-displayed artifacts include a rare surviving Soviet Ilyushin Il-2 airplane. (Opens July 1, 2026)
‚ÄúThe Ascent of Rauschenberg: Reinventing the Art of Flight‚Äù at the National Air and Space Museum
The work of artist Robert Rauschenberg is celebrated in this yearlong exhibition of 30 works. Flight was a consistent theme in Rauschenberg‚Äôs art, as he depicted birds, insects and spacecraft. (July 1, 2026, through summer 2027)
‚ÄúMuch Here Is Beautiful: Photography Surveys of the U.S. Bicentennial‚Äù at the Smithsonian American Art Museum
Just before the 200th birthday of the country in 1976, the National Endowment for the Arts created a multiyear program to help chronicle every corner of the States. The result, thousands of images from more than 200 photographers, allows a look at the nation a half-century ago. The museum presents a selection of images from the photography surveys just before and after the bicentennial, along with some from the 19th century. (September 18, 2026, through April 18, 2027)
Hirshhorn Sculpture Garden Reopening
The renovation of the sculpture garden, which began in 2023, was designed by Hiroshi Sugimoto, who previously redesigned the Hirshhorn Museum lobby. The sculpture garden, which is a little more than an acre, will feature selections from the museum‚Äôs growing collection of artwork, alongside favorite works such as Yoko Ono‚Äôs Wish Tree for Washington, D.C. (Opens fall 2026)
‚ÄúHandwork: Contemporary Craft‚Äù at the Renwick Gallery
In this exhibition, more than 100 objects shed light on the world of handmade crafts, including new acquisitions from artists Roberto Benavidez, Angela Ellsworth, Bill Harris, Aya Oki, Ato Ribeiro and Jan Yager. (Opens November 13, 2026)
‚ÄúPhotographic Memory: Fifty Years of Photography at the National Portrait Gallery‚Äù
The museum celebrates a half-century of its extensive photography collection by presenting more than 100 works, highlighting the significance of the medium in capturing the portraits of many who never posed for paintings or sculptures. The exhibition will include a recently acquired 1846 daguerreotype of Dolley Madison and the famous cracked-plate portrait of Abraham Lincoln, along with photos of Lee Miller, Ruth Asawa, James Brown and Serena Williams, among others. (Opens November 14, 2026)

Archaeologists Unearth a Reusable School Slate Still Covered in the Scribbles of Victorian Children
The slate was found alongside other evidence of young students‚Äô schoolwork and play at the site of a new development in London
Archaeologists have discovered a trove of rare artifacts used by children at the site of a new development in London.
While preparing for construction, researchers unearthed several marbles, a pencil and a fragment of a reusable slate tablet with letters scratched into the surface.
‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt often find archaeological objects we can directly link to children, but here we were delighted to find evidence for both schoolwork and play,‚Äù according to a January 12 update from the Museum of London Archaeology (MOLA), which is leading the dig.
The marbles‚Äîsome of which are still covered in colorful decorations‚Äîare what‚Äôs known as ‚Äúceramic alleys,‚Äù or small, smooth spheres designed to look like they were made from alabaster. They were discovered in a covered, brick-lined drain, which suggests they may have been lost during ‚Äúa breaktime game,‚Äù per MOLA.
The tablet, meanwhile, was probably a useful tool for taking notes. ‚ÄúChildren would have used chalk or slate pencils to copy down from the blackboard or practice their handwriting and rubbed them clean for the next lesson,‚Äù according to MOLA.
Archaeologists don‚Äôt know exactly how old the children‚Äôs artifacts are, but they hope to find out. They‚Äôre also trying to make out the scribbles on the tablet, per Fox News Digital‚Äôs Andrea Margolis.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre currently exploring this as part of our post-excavation work on the site, so we hope to be able to share more soon,‚Äù Alex Blanks, a MOLA senior archaeologist, tells the outlet.
The dig site, located in east London, will soon be home to SEGRO Park Wapping, a new industrial and logistics hub. However, hundreds of years ago, it was home to a free school for impoverished boys, as well as residences for poor elderly people.
The researchers say these structures were established in 1536 by Nicholas Gibson, an elected sheriff of London, and later supported by his widow, Avice Knyvet, who asked the Worshipful Company of Coopers to look after them.
The group made and repaired wooden casks and barrels in London starting in the 1400s, but it also supported charities and education initiatives. Many residents of the community had direct links to the profession‚Äîsuch as a father, husband or son who worked as a cooper.
According to a 1598 survey of London, the structures were ‚Äúfor the instruction of 60 poor men‚Äôs children, a schoolmaster and usher with fifty pounds ... also ... alms houses for 14 poor aged persons, each of them to receive quarterly six shillings and eight pence the piece for ever,‚Äù per MOLA. The homes‚Äô first inhabitants were primarily older, widowed women, but by 1720, men were also living at the site, records show. Each resident had a room, a cellar and a small garden.
In addition to the children‚Äôs items, archaeologists also unearthed the remains of a chapel, row houses and other buildings, as well as brick-lined cesspits and wells filled with items. The dig revealed a ‚Äúlittle microcosm of a whole community,‚Äù Blanks tells BBC News‚Äô Tim Stokes.
The excavation turned up artifacts ranging from the Roman occupation of London (from the first to the fifth centuries) to the Victorian period (from 1837 to 1901), including pieces of glassware, pottery and clay pipes.
Did you know? Ch√¢teau Margaux
The prestigious French vineyard Ch√¢teau Margaux was a favorite of famous figures like Thomas Jefferson, America‚Äôs third president, and Robert Walpole, Britain‚Äôs first prime minister.
Archaeologists also recovered the seal from a bottle of wine produced by a high-end French winery called Ch√¢teau Margaux. That was a bit of a surprise, because the area‚Äîwhich was once known as Sailor Town‚Äîwas long considered ‚Äúovercrowded and dangerous,‚Äù Blanks says in a statement.
‚ÄúBut finds like this are revealing a more complex social history than often biased contemporary sources would have you believe,‚Äù he adds. ‚ÄúIn reality, it was a very diverse area‚Äîjust like the East End is today. Archaeological evidence ... suggests people from a wide range of social standings may have been living in the area and getting to enjoy some of the same luxuries as the richest in society.‚Äù

articles.content:
An Asian Elephant Was Born at the Smithsonian‚Äôs National Zoo for the First Time in Almost 25 Years. Now, You Can Help Pick Her Name
The calf was born to 12-year-old Nhi Linh, a first-time mother, and 44-year-old Spike. The pair bred as part of a program working to conserve the endangered species
In the wee hours of February 2, the world welcomed a new Asian elephant. She is the first calf of this species born at the Smithsonian‚Äôs National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute (NZCBI) since late 2001.
Soon after the baby‚Äôs birth at 1:15 A.M. Eastern Standard Time, staff performed a neonatal exam and deemed her ‚Äúhealthy, alert and bright-eyed,‚Äù according to a statement. At the time, she weighed 308 pounds and measured 38.5 inches tall.
Assisting with the exam is ‚Äúreally hard to describe, because it‚Äôs something I‚Äôve wanted to do for years,‚Äù Robbie Clark, elephant manager and acting curator of Elephant Trails at NZCBI, tells Smithsonian magazine. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm honestly still absorbing what happened. I haven‚Äôt slept since she was born.‚Äù
This bundle of joy was born to first-time mother Nhi Linh, who is 12 years old, after a 21-month-long pregnancy. She bred with 44-year-old Spike in April 2024. The calf will not be viewable by Zoo visitors for up to a month while she bonds with her mom, the rest of the herd and animal care staff.
The baby doesn‚Äôt have a name yet, and NZCBI wants the public to help choose it. From today through February 13 at 12 P.M. Eastern Standard Time, fans who donate at least $5 to Asian elephant care and conservation through the Zoo‚Äôs website can choose from four options of Vietnamese origin, and $1 represents one vote:
Linh Mai [LIN-my]: Linh means ‚Äúspirit‚Äù or ‚Äúsoul‚Äù; Mai refers to the apricot blossom, a flower associated with T·∫øt (Lunar New Year), which begins February 17.
Th·∫£o Nhi [TOW-nee]: Th·∫£o means ‚Äúgentle‚Äù or ‚Äúkind‚Äù and is associated with nature; Nhi means ‚Äúsmall,‚Äù ‚Äúlittle one‚Äù or ‚Äúbeloved.‚Äù
T√∫ Anh [TOO-ahng]: T√∫ means ‚Äútalented‚Äù or ‚Äúgifted‚Äù; Anh means ‚Äúbright‚Äù and ‚Äúintelligent.‚Äù
Tuy·∫øt [TWET]: traditionally means ‚Äúsnow,‚Äù referencing the calf‚Äôs winter birth.
NZCBI will announce the calf‚Äôs name on its website in late February.
Parents Nhi Linh and Spike bred as part of a Species Survival Plan program, managed by the Association of Zoos and Aquariums, that aims to create a stable, genetically diverse population of Asian elephants. Fewer than 52,000 of these animals are estimated to remain in their homeland of South and Southeast Asia. ‚ÄúAsian elephants are very endangered. Actually, they‚Äôre ten times more endangered than African Elephants,‚Äù Peter Leimgruber, NZCBI‚Äôs director of conservation and science, tells Smithsonian magazine.
The species‚Äô population continues to dwindle largely because of human-induced habitat loss from activities such as agriculture, mining and urbanization. But insights gained at the Zoo can help conservationists working with wild Asian elephants.
‚ÄúMany of the things we learn here‚Äîtechnologies, the science‚Äîwe can directly transfer to these places [where the animals live],‚Äù Leimgruber says. For example, staff could show people how to monitor the elephants‚Äô reproductive cycles via hormones and determine which individuals should be bred to maintain genetic diversity, he notes.
Genetics, health and temperament helped experts determine that Spike and Nhi Linh should breed. Nhi Linh is described as having a ‚Äúfeisty and rambunctious‚Äù personality, per the statement. She arrived in the fall of 2022, along with her mother, 22-year-old Trong Nhi, as a gift from the Rotterdam Zoo in the Netherlands. Meanwhile, Spike seems to have a ‚Äúrelaxed and easygoing‚Äù personality, according to keepers, and came to NZCBI in the spring of 2018 on loan from Zoo Miami.
Fun fact: The last Asian elephant born at NZCBI
Male elephant Kandula was born at the Zoo on November 25, 2001. He left NZCBI when he was almost 14 years old and now lives at the Oklahoma City Zoo. His mother, Shanthi, stayed in Washington, D.C., and died at the estimated age of 45 in 2020.
Zoo staff have been carefully monitoring Nhi Linh over the past few months. In late January, blood draws revealed that her levels of the hormone progesterone had plummeted‚Äîa signal that she would soon give birth. On January 25, the care team began an around-the-clock watch to keep an eye out for behavioral signs of labor, such as tail flapping and abdominal muscle contractions.
A big indicator is something called the bulge. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs when the calf has moved with contractions to a point where you can see externally it‚Äôs pushing and getting ready to move,‚Äù Clark says. That happened soon after 12:30 A.M. Eastern Standard Time on February 2, he adds, ‚Äúand within a half hour, her water had broken and the calf was on the ground.‚Äù
The calf has not yet met her mother. The two can smell and hear one another, but a barrier sits between them. Staff are watching behavioral cues to assess when Nhi Linh might be ready to meet her baby. An encouraging sign that they‚Äôre currently seeing is Nhi Linh being the only elephant to respond to the calf‚Äôs calls, Clark says.
‚ÄúOnce we can secure that bond‚Äîand typically, the magic point is nursing‚Äîthen we‚Äôll give them a little time to learn how to orientate around each other,‚Äù he says.

articles.author: Reda√ß√£o
articles.excerpt: Directly where the Rhine meets the Moselle, The Thumb rises with quiet confidence near the Ludwig Museum, transforming the tranquil sculpture garden into a moment of playful awe. Created by C√©sar Baldaccini, the monumental form is among the most celebrated versions of his original Le Pouce in Paris‚Äî
